qas.question: What is the force equivalent of torque compared to angular momentum?

answers.text: angle is the rotational equivalent for position

qas.question: What would change the rotational inertia of a body under Newton's First Law of Motion?
To calculate instant angular acceleration of a rigid body what would you use?
What inertia exists because of Newton's Fourth Law of Motion?
What equation is torque like regarding velocity?
What is the rotational equivalent of velocity?
Which of Newton's Laws described a rotational inertia equation?

context: <b5_0>Torque<b5_0/> is the <a0_1>rotation<a0_1/> equivalent of force in the same way that <a0_3>angle is the <a0_0>rotational equivalent for position<a0_3/><a0_0/>, <b4_0>angular<b4_0/> velocity for velocity, and angular momentum for momentum. As a consequence of Newton's <b6_0>First Law of Motion<b6_0/>, there exists <a0_2><b3_0>rotational<b3_0/> inertia<a0_2/> that ensures that all bodies maintain their angular momentum unless acted upon by <a1_3>an <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>unbalanced torque<a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. Likewise, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3>Newton's Second Law of Motion<a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> can be used to derive an analogous equation for the instantaneous angular acceleration of the rigid body:
